reviewText:
This is not a bad game at all. Despite the fact that it's not sandbox-style like Guerrilla, it's still amazing.
The ability to destroy, reconstruct and destroy again is just fabulous and I can assure you that it will keep you entertained for hours.
The story is just a regular story. Fend off a horde of ugly and disgusting aliens and kill them ALL.
In simple words: Collect salvage, purchase upgrades and kill everybody with style.
You can choose between an impressive armory and going berserker with your sledge-hammer.
Short, simple gameplay but very fun.

Pros:

-The weapons are very fun to use and there is a good variety of them.
-Mechs, planes and tanks

Cons:

-The destructible environment can become a problem in some levels.

Neutral:

This game is nothing like Guerrilla. If you are looking for a cool story driven, linear shooter with some destructibility in it, this is the game for you.

reviewText:
Short game, but tons of fun. The weapons are some of the most unique I've ever come across, and are worth the purchase of the game. The game itself is narrow and linear, with awesome graphics (DX11) and decent voice-acting. Get it on sale and get ready for a fun 10 or so hours.

After finishing the game, I wanted to do more in the game world, but didn't want to play through the campaign again. Ruin mode (destroy the environment) is a lot of fun, but there are not enough maps and only two modes: Free Play and Challenge. Multi-player is fighting waves of enemies, in either Survive mode (what it says) or Defend mode (repair / defend something while waves of enemies attack). There are eight multiplayer maps, each in two varieties for 16 maps in all.

The Path to War" DLC
recommended: is a series of four missions that tie into the main campaign. There doesn't seem to be any reason for them to exist. Maybe the missions were rejected from the main campaign but the dev team were perhaps proud of the level design and released them anyway. The missions are fun

reviewText:
This is a very good game. The reviews on it made me anticipate pure trash but I ended up enjoying it just as much as the original. I think you should go into this and treat the game as it's own, not a Guerrilla sequel because it's far more linear.

Pros: Inventive Weapons, Cool upgrades, Enemy variety, Geomod Engine, Decent mission variety, Better salvage system than in Guerrilla(IMO), Badass missions with Spider Walkers and Mechs.

Cons: Occasionally braindead AI, Awful upgrade station placement (Seriously, one was placed at 44% Story progression when the new tier of upgrades came at 45%...Seriously Volition?), Crappy enemies(aliens jump around everywhere and they deal low damage so they're typically just annoying pests), Linear

reviewText: Red Faction Armageddon is a suprisingly good game that unfortunately saw only tepid performance in the marketplace.  The DirectX 11 visuals, physics engine, wide variety of weapons as well as a multiplayer/co-op mode make for a solid third person shooter.  Where the game fails however is in it's lackluster narrative and on the rails play.  The game feels very linear, which is a disappointment after the open world experience of Red Faction Guerilla.  With that said however, there is enough good gameplay and solid voice acting to make this game an enoyable but flawed title.
voteText: 54 of 69 people (78%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
My first Red Faction game was 2, followed by Guerilla - I really, really enjoyed both.

There have been a lot of negative reviews for this one, but most of those compare Armageddon far too strongly (and unfairly) to Guerilla. Notice that this game is called Red Faction: Armageddon, NOT Red: Faction Guerilla 2.

That being said, if you are a fan of the series, like third-person action shooters, and environment destructibility, then you will really, really enjoy this game.

The aesthetics are great, with absolutely fantastic environmental destruction depending on what weapon you use. The music and sounds are good. The story is decent, plot and gameplay progression is considerably more linear than Guerilla's open-world freedom, however, you should not be coming in to this game expecting it to be Guerilla 2.

The controls are easy to familiarize yourself with and the learning curve is minimal to moderate.

There is a horde mode that can be played local co-op or online multiplayer (or even solo) that is extremely fun. You unlock the levels you beat and can start at whatever wave you have unlocked. Solo playthrough is fairly challenging but doable if you keep practicing.

There is also a destruction mode that is insanely fun. You can choose whichever weapon loadout to use (you can swap weapons by going back to the equipment console) and just destroy everything in the environment. The magnet gun is amazing - shoot two (applicable) areas and the lighter object will fly toward the heavier one. Most of the weapons available will easily cut through most buildings and materials. You can play without a time limit or try the challenges - clearing the level within a time limit.

If you like third-person shooters with a lot of action and colossal amounts of destruction, give this game a try.

Highly recommend!

reviewText:
It's easy to see why a lot of people didn't like this game - Guerilla gave you an open-world and some really cool weapons to play with whilst this puts you into a corridor/tunnel and throws insects at you pretty much constantly.

As a linear shooter it's actually pretty decent - the enemies aren't just dumb targets, you'll need to move and use the right weapons at the right times etc. - but all of the demolition from earlier games is a sideshow here and whilst the nanoforge 'rebuilding' stuff is a really cool effect, it's role in the game is even less central (it's a minor puzzle element at best)

So as part of the series it's a let-down, but as a 'bug hunt' shooter it's actually fine - expectations adjusted, you'll probably enjoy it.

reviewText:
This a decent 3ps with a bit of horrorish touch. The storyline could be better though.

Pros-
> Destructible environment, use it to your advantage.
> Repair ability, use it to create makeshift cover and stuff. Also undo whatever destruction you wreaked so you don't have to pay fines.
> Semi rpg like sort of level up system (you use loot points to add new abilities).
> Decent length.
> All the exotic guns are pretty much designed to aid the kill-your-enemy-using-environment thing.

Cons-
> There are still bugs and some graphical glitches.
> Missions are too linear without any side quests or multiple routes to complete objective.
> Mostly corridor like segments with little room to maneuver.

Overall it is good shooter but not worth the current price tag. Try it out when it is on sale very cheap.
P.S.- I got it for just 1.63 USD at our local game store. So try to get retail versions, they are waaaaaaaaaaaay cheaper.

reviewText: Even if you're ok with this being nothing like the previous game this is a big disappointment. They decided to focus on combat this time which would be fine if it was satisfying. Unfortunately you spend most of the game fighting insect creatures which are only tedious to fight against. Even the biggest strenght of the Red Faction series, environment destruction, is mostly ignored towards the last third of the game when you're stuck fighting in a series of tunnels.\n\nIt's not a horrible game, just completely mediocre and forgettable. I would just replay Guerrilla if you're in the mood for Red Faction.

reviewText:
Red Faction: Armageddon was quite a surprise.

I got it way back in the THQ Humble Bundle on December 6th of last year, and up until now went unplayed. What a fool I was not to have tried it until now! It's a great game, and to have gotten it in a bundle? *mindblown*

Armageddon is a Third-Person Shooter that puts you in the shoes of Ex-Red Faction member Darius Mason on the surface of Mars. After a series of events spanning a few years, you are set on the path to stop a madman from destroying the planet. Along you way you will face thousands of alien lifeforms hellbent on your demise.

But do not worry! You have plenty of weapons with which to arm yourself. The most notable of which is the Nano Forge, a glove-like apparatus that can not only project a burst of force ahead of you, knocking back anything in its way, but can also repair ANYTHING in your environment. Found an Upgrade Station or Weapons Locker, but accidently blew it up in a battle against aliens? Come to a broken bridge that halts your advance? NO PROBLEM! Just use the Nano Forge's Repair ability to fix everything right up in seconds! You will definitely make use of this tool because literally about 98% of what you see on screen (terrain, buildings, etc) can be blown to bits. Other nifty weapons include the trusty Shotgun, 2 different sets of twin pistols (standard Pistols and later the significantly more powerful pair of Banshees <3 ), and even a Singularity Cannon, which fires a mini black hole which sucks in all around it, then explodes!

One of the mose useful tools, but one that some might consider the game's way of holding your hand"

reviewText: This game deviated from the more open world predecessor. The more linear storyline, however, has a decent script and quality syfy acting, and the controlled environments make for some interesting shootouts. A wide array of weaponry provides variety while destroying the games destructible environments. New Game Plus enhances the games replayability. Altogether a worthy addition to the Red Faction collection.

reviewText: I literally could not finish this game.  I'll admit the rebuilding and magnetic gun thingers were cool, but the rest of the game is a flat linear corridor shooter that wishes it was Doom 3 or Resident Evil.  The plot is painful and the combat is repetitive when it isn't unfair or tediously frantic.  GeoMod is utterly wasted in this game, mostly used for stuff that a scripted destruction could have done.  It's limited too: unlike the first game, which also took place in the cramped tunnels in Mars' surface, you CANNOT blow up terrain.  No making your own tunnels to get past the tedium, because that would let you bypass the riveting on-rails experience.\n\nThis is the worst game in the series, worse even than Red Faction 2.  It's ironic, given that this has some of the coolest advancements in what GeoMod can do.

reviewText: I will say one thing about this game: don't be a ♥♥♥♥ and deny it's good aspects purely because it's not open world like Guerrilla. If you've ever liked a linear, story driv- well, oriented shooter there's no discernible reason you won't like this. It might not touch your heart strings as much as say, Gears of War ('cos we all know how much of an emotional roller coaster that piece of overrated ♥♥♥♥ was) but it's got everything you need in a story and that's an incentive to play the game. The actual gameplay is pretty good, I enjoyed it at least. There's a variety of weapons, although you'll find your best suited 4 and probably won't use any others much after a while. Destructible environments are always fun and no one does them better than Volition.The repair... erm, thingy is not just a gimmick, it's not only a workaround for the occasional issue with destructible environments whereby you accidentally destroy the way forward but they've also made it actually useful by allowing you to repair cover and certain other things that are necessary to progress. I realize that was more than one thing but all in all there's not a lot to say about this game except don't be deterred by the fact that it's not open world like it's predecessor. That is my only reason for writing this review so just give it a chance. Who knows, you might find yourself enjoying it a little... scary thought for some I know.

reviewText:
Ups:
-Terrain destruction is amazing
-Infestation Mode is intense and can get challenging
-Variety of weapons (however some of them feel useless compared to others)
-Aliens are generally fun to fight
-Some of the guns are freaking hilarious to kill aliens with (Magnet gun anyone?)
-In the few short missions that you use a vehicle, you feel unstoppable and badass.

Downside:
-Quite Short gameplay time, no openworld exploration (apart from free mode, which is just a tiny map)
-Can be repetitive in some areas, especially when the same aliens keep popping up.
-Game crashed once or twice when I pressed a button in game.
-Can feel like it's all going way too fast (might not be a bad thing in your case)

Conclusion: I've only ever played Armageddon and Guerilla from the Red Faction series. I found Guerilla to give me more entertainment since it was open world and the destruction you caused wasn't limited to a level. However, Armageddon still gave me a solid 8-10 hours gameplay offline, which only included the campaign, a few infestation levels and about an hour mucking about in free roam. I have not tried Online and there are plenty more things to do in offline mode (achievements, secrets, harder difficulties, etc.) Graphics wise the game was OK. I was playing the game off a new-ish laptop and everything ran fine, however I don't think graphics are on par with games that came out around the same time. But hey, don't judge a book by it's cover, right?
I definitely recommend this game to any one looking for intense FPS destruction game. I payed $5 when it was on sale, however I think the original price of $20 is worth it, especially if you can get some friends in on it. Rating: 7/10

reviewText:
Download size: about 8 gigabytes if I remember correctly
Play time: about 8 hours (with the DLC)

Red Faction Armageddon (RFA) is the latest in a series of games made famous for their “destroy the environment” gameplay. Like its predecessors, in RFA you can use your sledgehammer or guns to blow apart basically anything that is “manmade” in the game. This includes walls, bridges, and entire buildings. You can’t break through “natural” obstacles like cave walls, the floor, or most rocks on the ground. A lot of people I’ve spoken to seem to think that RFA is a step down from the previous game Red Faction Guerilla, but I like RFA more. For one thing, it’s much more straightforward and action based (Guerilla was an open world sandbox game like Grand Theft Auto on Mars).

You don’t need to have played the previous games to get into Red Faction Armageddon since this game takes place a generation or two after Guerilla. Now the “Red Faction” is the legitimate military of Mars and you’re one of them (in the previous games they were rebels). In RFA you play Darius Mason, an engineer with an artificial intelligence computer companion named Sam who helps you out, like Cortana in the Halo series. Your enemy is Hale, some kind of cult leader who tricks you into unleashing an ancient alien race sealed deep underground. The rest of the game is spent trying to fix your mistake.

RFA is a third person “over the shoulder” shooter game with a variety of weapons and “super powers.” The super powers are part of the Nano Forge technology that Darius wears on his wrist and can get you out of any jam. You have Impact (a force push), Shockwave (lifts up enemies around you), Berserk (some kind of damage buff), and Shell (an area effect shield).  All of the powers share the same cooldown bar. Money in the game is “salvage” just like Red Faction Guerilla. Salvage is glowing junk that is left over when you blow stuff up and can also be found just lying around. You mostly spend the salvage upgrading your character, but you can also unlock cheats like infinite ammo or vehicle weapons (guns that are usually mounted on vehicles but you can now use when walking around).

Speaking of vehicles, there are a bunch of times when you get into an EXO suit or an assault walker and run around blowing stuff up with your heavy weapons. In the Path to War DLC for the game, you spend most of the time in vehicles. The DLC adds about 2 hours more gameplay and a few easy achievements.

I haven’t tried the multiplayer much since the game has been out long enough that nobody’s playing online anymore. You can use the “Infestation” game mode to grind for more salvage since Infestation shares the same unlocks as the single player campaign. Any upgrades you buy in Infestation (except cheats) can be used during the campaign and vice versa.  Infestation is a survivor mode where you just kill waves of aliens, which get more powerful as you progress. It can get boring fast though, since you don’t really get penalized for dying (and there’s nobody to play with).

Pros:
+Excellent graphics and story. The aliens are freaky looking and it’s always fun blowing stuff up. The game mostly takes place underground, but there are a lot of buildings that you can bring crashing down. The Nano Forge can also repair broken things, so if you accidently destroy a ladder or stairs, you can rebuild it in seconds.
+In one playthrough of the game you can unlock most of the skills, and there is a new game+ option where you can start over, keeping everything you bought. During the second playthrough you’ll get enough salvage to unlock all the upgrades you missed, plus a couple of cheats, which can be used for higher difficulty levels. The cheats do NOT disable Steam achievements.

Cons:
-Multiplayer is dead. You won’t find anyone to play with online unless you set it up beforehand.
-Like most over the shoulder games, you might get a headache the first few times you play. It varies by person though, and you’ll get used to the perspective eventually.

Overall, the game is great and you should give it a try if you haven’t already. A lot of people probably got this game from the THQ bundles back when THQ was going out of business. The main game takes maybe 7 hours to beat, so you can finish it in a weekend and rake in a few Steam achievements while you’re at it. You get about half the achievements just playing through the game one time.

reviewText: The basic mechanics – Geo-Mod, guns, camera, movement – are all intact and sound, but Red Faction Armageddon can't think of anything better to do with them but an hours-long, inescapably linear, exhausting slog with no sense of pacing whatsoever and a laughably pathetic storyline. This game might feature the best sniper rifle I've ever had the joy to use, but it still somehow manages to suck all the fun out of killing things.

reviewText:
well, this game took a step backwards....we went from RFG and it's sandbox nature to RFA which is very linear.  However, the game does still have some interesting level design, once you get out of the first couple of levels.

The story was actually better than expected.  darius and Kara were the only characters i really cared about, and thats fine because they were highlighted more than others anyway.  I did find myself using many weapons throughout the game, and not so much just the sledgehammer like i did in RFG.  In this game the weapons seemed to be more balanced, and considering there is more z-axis fighting, you might need some long range weaponry to aid you here.  Sorry, no jet pack like in RFG.

All in all a solid game, worth a run through, and the co-op is pretty decent too.  The DLC was pretty forgettable though.  Felt like levels that were cut from the basr game and reinstalled as DLC.  Plus, the first DLC level in the canyon just kept going forever.

Base Game; 7.0/10
DLC 3.5/10

reviewText:
Red Faction Armageddon
Rating 7/10
Overview: Linear Third Person Shooter

The Good:

+ Varied locations, despite taking place on Mars every location feels unique and varied.

+ Good sense of pacing, the game introduces new vehicles, enemies, weapons throughout the journey to keep things fresh

+ Variety of different weapons that are very unique and fun to use that fit different play styles.

+ Like previous Red Faction Games, this game features impressive building destruction.

+ Solid controls

+ Destroying buildings, killing enemies allows you to gain salvage which is used to upgrade your character, weapons and abilities

+ Infestation Mode (Horde Mode) allows you to fight wave after wave of enemies.


The Average:


Ruin Mode allows you to destroy environments within a time limit to score as many points as you can. It is a great idea that seems very underutilized given it only has a handful of maps. The previous Red Faction game had the same mode but it was much more fleshed out in its execution so this was a bit of a disappointment.

The game has a lot of enemy variation but it certainly doesn't feel that way. For most of the game you will be fighting the same 3 types of enemies over and over again.

Main campaign will take around 6 hours to complete

The DLC is decent but also very short. The levels are not as well designed as the main campaign.


The Bad:

- The story is decent if a bit simple in its premise, it doesn't feel as developed as it should and serves more as an excuse to kill hordes of enemies. Given the location and history of Red Faction it seems like wasted potential.

- Multiplayer achievements which are now almost impossible to obtain.


Conclusion

I can't recall another series that has had more changes each entry than Red Faction. The first game was a linear first person shooter similar to half life. The second was a level based first person shooter with bosses. The third was an open world third person shooter. This game is a linear level based third person shooter with upgrades. At this rate its only a matter of time before we see Red Faction the real time strategy game. This is a good game but plays it entirely safe with its gameplay and design. The potential is here for something special but never achieves it.

reviewText:
Red Faction: Armageddon is... Dull

Linear, boring, cliched and utterly dissapointing are the words which jump to mind. This FPS action title is the follow up to the hugely successful Red Faction: Guerilla, the open world masterpiece. Sadly, someone sitting in the finance department must have decided that the strings needed tightening and that they should pursue an on rails FPS, and everything went ♥♥♥♥ up from there sadly.

There should be a strong story here, which follows the Red Faction universe, but instead theres a shadow of a story and a ton of bugs. There should be a ton of destruction and some great hammer battles, but instead theres a limited field of a play to smash up and then little to no reason to whip out the hammer.

So the key question.. is this even worth purchasing? Honestly, the campaign is quite long and it's not the most awful game I've ever played, maybe. So I would suggest a purchase price of no more than £3.

Notes
Achievements, No Trading Cards, Controller Support

reviewText: Red Faction: Armageddon is the Fourth game in the Red Faction series and the first game of the series I have played. The game is played in third-person, both as a single player campaign and in multiplayer mode. The story revolves around Terraforming operations on Mars and hostile Martian creatures who attack your Terraformer. The environment is destructible which is a departure from a lot of shooter-type games, and makes Red Faction particularly fun to play. Visually speaking, Red Faction: Armageddon seems pretty average for a shooter, though it was released in 2011. The story doesn't seem all that deep, but you do get to blow stuff up and rampage out, so I suppose like a hollywood movie, if you can't win them over with story, just add explosions. I give it a thumbs up, though I think there are better Shooters out there with more depth.

reviewText: [7/10] - Red Faction games in general have a unique style and feeling that creates a very familiar, yet fun and creative experience for everyone individually.  The destruction is fantastic, and the replayability just because of that is very high. However, I feel they didn't deliver as best as they could have with this title. The physics, story and gameplay are all excellent, however it just didn't deliver as hard as expected. That aside, don't overlook this game altogether as it still has some fantastic moments. I definitely recommend you play this at least once if you're a fan of any Red Faction titles.

reviewText: Great cathartic potential marred by every technical bug imaginable. Graphics bugs, physics bugs, freeze-ups, crashes to desktop and disappearing sound are so common they're infuriating. When the game actually works, it's a pretty decent third-person shooter with great destructive enviroment gimmick and well paced combat. Poor checkpoint placement and linear levels aren't really a problem since the game is well aware of its strengths and always throws something new, be it a new weapon, turret section or putting you in control of nearly indestructible mech and telling you to go nuts.\nBut again, frequent stability issues kept breaking the flow of the game and ultimately made me quit.\nIf developers didn't care enough to fix these bugs in a 3-year old title, why should I ? Terrible PC port. Get it  on a sale or even better, play Red Faction Guerilla. A much better, albeit open-ended experience.

reviewText:
+ Destruction physics  engine lived up to its predecessor; everything was delightfully destructible and an absolute delight to blow up
+ Weapon variations were very, very fun to shoot
+ The nanoforge added a lot of fun to the game, such as being able to repair structures (very well-done in the game), and being able to create nanomachine shields around you in cobat
+ While the game is mostly just point and shoot, the developers managed to successfully break up the monotony by periodically adding new weapon drops and various types of mech suits/aircraft
+ Additional game-modes add a lot of replay value, such as co-op horde mode and freeroam destruction

- Bland, forgettable story and characters
- Short game (~6-7 hours for campaign)
- Dialogue was campy and generic

reviewText:
Product received for free

Red Faction Armageddon looks like a sci-fi shooter game. Red Faction has been made of one of my favourite game developers when I was a kid; THQ.

When I first time played the game I was already starting at the battlefield to hunt down some rebels. In the game you can carry up to four weapons max. The game starts with two weapons: a Maul, an assault rifle and you can find more weapons in the same level as well. At the first mission you will also have a hand that could repair the damaged objects in the environment, but the hand can only repair in a close distance between you and the damaged objects in your surroundings. In the game you can purchase upgrades with the salvages that you can find somewhere around in the game.

The game takes place in the peaceful Mars. The peace there was threatened, because of the rebels who wanted to avange the loss of their boss. His family was killed by an important person of the military. This turned out a war with the military and the rebels. And there was also an another problem: at a mysterious wise turned out: that there were Aliens in a underground cave.

My impressions of the game.

The game looks in my opinion a bit like one of the games that was made by THQ, meet the Robinsons on the Wii. I came to that impression by one of the boss fights with Adam Hale and in the Robinsons Mega-Doris.

Pros and Cons of the game.

Pros:

-	The graphics of the game is modern
-	The gameplay is so amazing, that you most of the times can forget how late it is
-	Lots of varieties in weapons
-	The hand repair function is amazing to use

Cons:
-	The game looks a little bit like meet the Robinsons on the Wii
-	The game needs more varieties in Aliens
-	You’ll sometimes die randomly

I'd say buy this game only if it is in a sale for a nice price.


Received a free copy for testing/reviewing purposes. This review is part of the Steamified Community Review program. For similar reviews and fantastic giveaways please visit http://www.steamified.com/.

reviewText:
To this date, this is the last game in the Red Faction franchise. It has performed rather poorly in sales and it's easy to see why.

There is no more revolution or fight against oppression (which would mean human opponents), in it's stead - bug-like aliens take place. It reminds me of Alien Swarm or Alien Breed but with a much higher level of quality and that AAA feel to it. It's a rather decent game with the physics and destruction being improved, some very nice weapons and fairly challenging difficulty.

The storyline isn't bad. In fact it's much better then any of the new blockbusters.
A special place holds the music in my mind, it's not only a new style for the franchise, but a very well made artistic move that revolves around a more claustraphobic environement - like the first Red Faction and second Red Faction games to a degree.

I also can't help but regret that the socialistic revolution theme was somewhat left aside.


It feels as if the identity on first glance changed, leaving nothing but the destruction aspect as a standing-out feature. In the end THQ went bankrupt and Nordic games took it's place releasing a little bit of content for free. Thank you Nordic Games!
The style is much too different. But don't be fooled by that, it's still a worth conclusion to a story that went on for 10 years with an amazing aesthetic value.

reviewText:
Red Faction: Armageddon focuses on destructible environments. The player must reclaim cultist fortifications on the disaster-ravaged surface of the planet and defend colonists from hostile Martian creatures in the ancient mines and chasms beneath it and cleansing infestations from all structures.

Using the Magnet Gun, Darius, the main protagonist, fires first at one object, then at a second object, and then the first object rockets toward the second.

The Nano-Forge returns, having been passed down through two generations of the Mason family. Darius' father has incorporated the tool with a function that reverses any and all destruction dealt to man-made objects. The Nano-Forge will also feature an ability known as Impact, which discharges an incredibly powerful burst of force which can blow away structures and throw enemies off their feet.

Darius' Nano-Forge, weapons and armor are all upgradeable, improving their efficiency, unlocking new abilities, and altering their appearances.

reviewText:
well I played like half of the game so here's my review so far
Story: pretty generic just like the predecessors
Gameplay: WAY more linear than guerrilla, but with more diverse enemies. Armageddon is a third person shooter compared to guerrilla's free roam gameplay
Sound: Good, the music fits well, weapons feel decent and monsters don't sound half bad, voice acting is pretty good as well
Graphics: improved from Guerrilla, holds up today, can run on most rigs due to good optimization
STRONG POINTS: -Destruction system which is a trademark of the Red Faction series works very well here as well, being able to use a magnet gun to take down structures and throw them into enemies (or vice versa)
-Varied arsenal & upgrades system gives the game some slight replayability and gives you things to use in any situation
WEAK POINTS:
-Campaign has a very short length, I played 50% of the story within 3 hours
-Multiplayer is pretty much dead, not a lot of people online
-Moving can feel weird if you're coming from Guerrilla or the other RF's, since sprint is limited and jumping has a delay

Get this game on a sale, or pick it up along with the others in a pack. you WILL have lots of fun with this if you like toying around with physics and such

reviewText: Do not buy this game. I thankfully didn't (in a fashion), having gotten it as part of a THQ humble bundle (which I bought for Saints Row The Third), and so my rage at this game was far less than it would have been had I spent my cash on it. So what's wrong with it? It's a horrible sequel for one. Where Guerilla was a open world Sandbox that let you wreck tons of stuff as you pleased, this game is completely linear with basically no freedom of action. Guerilla didn't have an especially strong story, but the one here is even worse, with almost no likeable characters (especially not the main character you play as) and one of the few I did sorta like getting abruptly killed off late in the game. The gameplay is fine, but the other factors here helped to ruin the game for me. Also it's extremely short (Yes I beat the game with those hours played).\n\nIf you like Guerilla, just stick with that and pretend this game does not exist. Trust me. It's for the best.

In short, this game is no RF: Guerrilla. However, this game is still great fun and I thoroughly enjoyed playing through it. I bought the game on sale for $7.50 so perhaps that's why I'm not as critical when it comes to reviewing it. As someone who has little time and a lot of stress, this game provided me with an outlet to destress and I loved every minute of it. Sure, the sandbox is gone, but the destruction and carnage are still there. Nothing brought me more joy than bringing down an infected building with cool and creative weapons, or blasting through enemies with badass vehicles.

As an RF fan, I enjoyed the small touches they placed here and there to build upon the lore. Little things references to the RF history I thought were pretty cool and even how the Terraformer had the EDF symbols on it still were a nice touch.

Is the game a setback from Guerrilla? Yes, but not a huge one. It's definitely worth a playthrough, at least during a flash sale. It's great, mindless fun and decently long. The enemies, while perhaps a cross between the Flood and Necomorphs, are entertaining to cut down and you learn a good deal about the RF world in the process.

While not as good as the predecessor (Guerilla), as it lacks a more open-world experience, this game still provides a fairly good continuation of the storyline set up prior to the game. The nano forge concept provides a neat twist to aid in re/de constructing the environment.

This game has a black-hole gun and lets you crash through buildings in a giant mech while those buildings crumble and collapse in real time destruction.  Every weapon past the standard pistol/rifle/shotgun trio is designed specifically around how much damage it can wreak to the environment as well as the enemy and  once you're done destroying those environments you can rebuild them for navigation purposes which removes all the constraints that would normally apply to enviromental devastation.\n\nIf you need anything more than that, then you're doing videogames wrong.

Far exceeded my expectations. Definitely have to say this game receives unfair slack for going back to its roots. The additions to your arsenal, most notably the obvious: magnet gun and nanoforge, are so kicking rad and unique it's not even funny. While it's sad to see the open world go, the linear focus here makes the game as a whole much tighter, so you're not just going from one environment to another that's suspiciously similar and doing repetitive (if fun) destruction-based side quests.\n\nThey tried to turn the hero into Nathan Drake, with him halfheartedly making Whedon-esque quips in the face of danger every now and then. Not necessarily a bad decision. Better than faceless and boring. The story itself isn't bad: it's just there. Sitting. And...I don't feel like expanding anymore so I'm going to hurry up and get back to processing remotely-sensed data. Ugh.

I wanted to hate Armageddon, for removing the free roam feature that made Gurrila so amazing and fun with tones of re-play ability (I'm on my 13th re-play) sadly even without the free roam i loved and enjoyed RF: A a lot.

Story: Is ♥♥♥♥ i admit, wierd and complete unkown. Its is to drive the game forward though been a liniare game now.

Graphics: The game boast's DX11, destructable enviroments and amazing set pieces. A well rounded games with some intresting pieces.

Gameplay: Average 3rd person shooter with ♥♥♥♥ to blow up. A nice collection of epic new guns to play boom boom with.

Overall, the real times destruction would not be enough to win me over but huge bosses, an array of new epic guns such as the magnet gun and so on help keep RF: A an extreamly fun game. Whilst no wear near as good as Gurrila its worth a purchase if you loved Gurrila but wanted to shoot aliens i guess.

I have still to try the multiplayer.

8.0/10 - Good fun game with a few flaws

The corrupted saves seem to be a common complaint from what i can find on the internet. If you play this game, make sure to manually save your progress periodically.

However I am now done with this game.

I gave this game short shrift when it came out because it is not Red Faction: Guerrilla, nor does it resemble that excellent open-world game in anything but its screenshots.  I should have been more forgiving.  With time providing some distance and perspective, I can say that this is a thoroughly decent linear GeoMod shooter in the vein of early Red Faction games.  Its story feels a little out of place in the universe and I'm not sure its action will challenge veteran shooter fans, but the game is genuinely fun and engaging.  The weapon selection is by far the best thing about this game -- you can carry four at a time, and while they only superficially resemble the demolitions kit from Guerrilla, they satisfy the same itch for destruction.

Red Faction: Armageddon gets flak for being short and not living up to the acclaim of the previous title in the franchise, Guerilla. But it's still a good game.

You play as Darius Mason, the grandson of Alec Mason from Guerilla. Set fifty years after Guerilla, the premise is that the Cultists and their leader, Adam Hale take control of the terraformer, the machine which supplies Mars with its sustainable atmosphere. Darius, working with Red Faction forces, try to assault the terraformer and take back control. Ultimately, the Cultists end up destroying the terraformer and some time later, Darius is a contractor taking on drilling jobs in the underground. Things go awry when, on a certain drilling job he takes on, he awakens an infestation. Turns out he was set up and now he has to save the planet and bring order back to civilization. Along with some help.

The unique mechanic in this game is the nano energy and SAM. SAM is like Cortana, but not as emotional. She helps you decrypt things, unlock doors, give you power ups, etc. The nano energy is cool, like the repair mechanism so that you can rebuild bridges you need to cross over canyons or lava flows.

The enemies include both the Cultists and the infestation of bugs. The bugs were a dormant species living on Mars that Adam Hale had tricked Mason into waking. They're kind of what you'd expect, and more. They vary in size from flying little things that annoy you, to walking fiends that fire lasers at you. And giant behemoths that charge and shoot green gases at you. And tentacles that pummel you. Basically, there are plenty of enemies and you'll never be bored fighting them.

Most of the game takes place in the underground, and I think the devs really nailed Mars' undreground. Mars seems like the place where the underground would be vast and large with flowing lava in various places. But also gloomy and dreadful because life on Mars means being in constant fear of death from seperate factions or unknown species. Especially underground where there are unexplored territories and systems that may have been abandoned long ago. It's really interesting to think about, honestly. You don't see much topside beside the opening mission and maybe two or three more bits, but over 90% of the game is underground.

Everything else is nice too, graphics, sound design/mixing. Rarely any bugs. Music is a bit overkill with the guitars. I would have liked something more electronic to fit the mood of sci-fi action. Or at least more orchestral. But the guitars and drums didn't do it for me.

Anyway. The game's plot started iffy for me, but I grew into it and ended up really liking it. Also, start a new game plus after you beat it for the possibly the greatest weapon out there, Mr. Toots: a mini-unicorn you carry that shoots rainbow plasma from its booty.

8.5/10

You know I don't know why people sometimes hate on Red Faction games. I watched a review of this game at some point and the reviewer reflected on the fact that every second RF game is, apparently, a load of hooey.

Earlier today I reviewed Red Faction 2, and as I praised the title in that review then what I feel about this game should become clear: I like this game.

It has great graphics, fun gameplay with the mag gun sorta thing, great combat against aliens and some good challenges. I wasn't really looking for much more than what I got - interesting, utterly destructible environments, good graphics that ran smoothly, big booms and crashes and lots of enemies that presented a hazard but also went splat rather nicely. The story isn't all that bad either, even if it takes a back seat to the action, and of course it doesn't pay much attention to the Red Faction storyline of the first or third games but who gives a crap? It's a good game.

This game is really cool. It's kind of like Dead Space and Lost Planet combined. The look of the game is neat and the gameplay is awesome. lots of side stuff to do beside the main story It plays better with a controller.

reviewText:
I'll give it an 8/10 (on my  scale) . The single player campaign is pretty long and satisfying. Enjoyed most of the game like around 95% .Few part had too much enemies lol but it was fun dying at different places :P . The best part that i literally enjoyed was reconstruction. Since most the structures, actually almost everything, in the game is destructible hence it can be rebuilt too :3 too much fun. I dont care of the graphics but still for the sake of review just a comment 'pretty good'.

The bosses are pretty damn easy too kill(once you know where to attack), not VERY EASYYY but yes you wont die (max maybe once but not more than that). Lots of weapons but cannot carry then all well you get a lot of opportunities in the levels to change them according to your style. A hand full of upgrades but make sure you look out for nanites(the currency ingame to buy upgrades). They are spread out in almost every corner of the level even at places you dont neeed to visit. (just for sharing i - I was able to unlock around 85% of upgrades)

The one weapon which has a unique twist to it is the MAGNET GUN. Most guns would shoot, launch grenades or rockets or even vapourising beams but NO this gun?! well it shoots magnets powerful enough to destroy a whole building. The uniqueness isnt in this though, the uniquness lies in the fact that you can actually throw an aliens at stuff around you. And if not that you can go entirely opposite of it, throw stuff at the alien with it (everything else you'll get to know ingame not gonna spoil it all :P )

Once you finish the game you have 'NEW GAME +' too, just like most other games now-a-days. Also you have a few rewards once you complete the game which you get to use in 'NEW GAME +' mode ^_^

I highly recommend this game to those who are die hard shooting fans and of destruction.

ALL IN ALL I HAD A PRETTY GOOD TIME PLAYING THIS. I DID SOME EXPLORATION SO I HAD AN OVER ALL SINGLE PLAYER CAMPAIGN TIME OF 7:26 HOURS. (NOT VERY GOOD BUT IT WAS WORTH ). (y)

reviewText:
This isn't a bad shooter. The visuals are great, the AI is actually fairly difficult to deal with, the voice acting is good, the weapons are varied and the gameplay feels fluid and varied.

The one problem I have with this game is that there are parts in the game that feel like an endurance test. Another issue is that the storyline does not make sense in some parts and that the tunneling from the original game is missing. I assume that this is to prevent GPU-related housefires, but there is no reason why it can't be made an option.

I recommend this game to those who want a shooter with some personality that does not take itself too seriously.

reviewText:
After the great open world Red Faction Guerilla, Volition take the series in another direction. Stripping the open world in favour of a tight, linear structure turned a lot of people of to this game as did the focus on fighting alien bugs rather than a human threat. If you can play beyond the first third of the game however up to when you get back to the surface of Mars  the game does open up a little into more open canyons with some great vehicular destruction.
The game features the meatiest story in the series and follows directly on from the SyFy movie Red Faction origins with you playing another decendant in the Mason family responsible for allowing the Martian atmosphere processor to be destroyed by Cultists and in turn letting lose a whole nest of alien creatures from underground. The story ties back into the previous games and playing them first would be benifical.
Weapons are inventive and forceful and are fun to use, especially the mechs and tanks and their respective missions.
Visuals have gotten better from the last game and there is still destruction of buildings but this time you can bring anything back with the new Nano rebuilder to recreate destroyed stair ways etc so you are not stuck trying to climb the geometry to make progress after a fire fight which was a problem in guerilla.
The only problem is the Aliens are used a lot and are thrown against you overwhelmingly at some points so it can get a little repetative fighting them again and again.
Overall if you're coming back here for more of Guerilla you will be dissapointed but if you enjoyed the first game's structure or like linear shooters in general theres fun to be had here.

7.5/10

It might not be the best game it is worth every penny and when on sale it is a MUST BUY.

Have fun ^_^

reviewText:
Big part of the people who are interested in this game, are going to want it because of Red Faction: Guerilla. So I'll be adjusting my recommendation with that in context.

As comparisons go, the first one is as simple as this: The story is now lineair and you are no longer in a free-roaming world. With that, means that the walls surrounding your path are unbreakable. However, this doesn't mean that desctruction is very absent.

On the contrary, destruction and debris play a much bigger role than they did in Guerilla. In said game, your sledgehammer served for nothing to break down buildings, maybe kill those inside.

In Armageddon, debris is a potential weapon. The Magnet gun is the tool of the trade now. It's functioning is two-staged: You attach/shoot first what you want moved, then attach the second magnet to where you want it to go. This can be structure parts, pickups or even enemies (all but the biggest Behemoth).

This makes for some fun and unique gameplay. And while the tool is powerful and relatively fast, you'll still be needing some firearms. Because the Alien swarm is fast and massive.

Besides that, the weapons array is pretty much classic. Shotguns, Assault/Sniper rifles and two sets of dual pistols. The Sniper rifle does feature a heat-mode that allows you to see and headshot through surfaces, which is the only reason the sniper is not obsolete, as vantage points are nigh unexistant.

I won't spoil the story because... it's not that extraordinary. Saying anything about it may as well spoil it all. It's classic, a little bit cheesy but not too annoying.

S.A.M. however, that's a new box of toys. S.A.M. is your wrist-mounted A.I. that serves a guiding purpose in the story, and a more practical one in combat. You start out with a repair functionality. Anything destroyed can be repaired by the nano-forge that is built in.

Which means, you now have a new renewable weapon in debris, as well as a renewable cover source. Too bad there's no cover mechanic. Just crouching, and that's it.

The Impact skill basically serves as a short-range air bash that pushes back any debris in it's path. Of course, this makes the sledgehammer pretty obsolete. (which can now be swapped out)
It also makes for a nice punching weapon, though eventually you'll want to power it up with upgrades.

Besides that, you have three classical 'extra' skills you can get through the upgrade station. Berserk ups your damage and fire speed, Shockwave (that I didn't even bother to try) is a typical Nova ability, and the Shell works as a projectile shield (great for when you're almost dead) and DoT for enemies that are inside of it.

As per enemies go... it's a good thing your toys are more destructive rather than precision based. AFAIK 25% of the enemies you encounter are human. And they tend to be pushovers, even at Hard difficulty.

The real threat are the Alien creatures. They all come in several ranks, and tend to just swarm you late-game, with the low-rank creatures coming in masses and tending to be very melee based.

But, even on Hard mode, the only real threats are the Berserkers are the Behemoths. Berserkers are quite tough and are hard hitting on both ranged and melee. But they can just be punted around with the magnet gun and melee'd to death once you've taken care of the other critters.

Behemoths, when not encountered while in a vehicle, tend to be mini-boss fights. The area is locked off and you need to use your weapons or available debris to kill them. They're real bullet spunges and hit pretty hard in ranged and melee.
And they can't be punted around.

While in a vehicle, they are the only types of enemies that really pose a threat if not paid any attention to.
Eventually though, you'll find a gimmick that works for you and they just become a nuisance. Much like the other aliens, really.

This is a game with a gimmick that plays it very, very well. But sadly, it can't lean on it to justify a full price. Maybe if it had been free-roaming. But regardless, the game is not something you should avoid simply because of that.

reviewText:
This game feels like it was made by talented developers following a checklist, with no regard to how the game will be received and whether the end result will be any fun. They were told to make another entry in the Red Faction franchise, so they did, got paid and moved on. I'll skip ahead and say that this game really should not exist, and it's not fun after 3-4 hours in.

The game's campaign is roughly 10 hours long, even on the highest difficulty. Most of the game is spent fighting the same 3-4 enemy types in same-looking caves. The protagonist has a ton of health and regenerates quickly, the enemies are mostly armed with peashooters, and fighting them is about as difficult as playing a cow clicker game. Most of the environment is so generic and forgettable, I couldn't recall most of the game even immediately after I finished it.

The destruction engine the Red Faction series is known for is there, but roughly two thirds of the environment are indestructible. Regardless, wrecking the destructible parts of the environment while enemies are in/on top of it is virtually the only fun aspect in the game.

Literally every level in the game is at least twice as long as it should be, dragging on so much that I had to take breaks to do something else in order to stay awake. You would think that destroying the environment inside a walker mech armed with infinite missiles never gets old, but it does - every single vehicle scene repeats at least twice, involves no challenge and no risk of dying, and consists of mashing mouse1 for 10 or more minutes.

While you can technically have fun in the game if you play it in short bursts and don't treat it seriously, the final 3 levels are disgustingly bad and *will* make you hate it. It feels like THQ told Volition the game should be at least 10 hours long, and they struggled to add enough filler to hit the 10 hour mark.

There is a reason this game sold so poorly that THQ decided to terminate the Red Facton franchise. Good riddance.

reviewText:
Wow this feels like such a let-down after Guerrilla. I adore RF Guerrilla but this does away with almost everything that made that game so good.

- No open world, no exploration, no freedom at all from what I have played
- No human enemies, or very few (apparently there are some a bit later on)
- Tedious gameplay mechanics such as mobbing you with aliens
- Worse destruction engine, I think. Just doesn't look as impressive as before.

Upsides?

- Overall improved graphics
- The aliens do look quite cool

So yeah... not recommended. Just get Guerrilla... or play it twice as much!

reviewText:
Let me start off by saying that I hated Guerilla. I gave it at least 3 separate tries and on each occasion I felt dumber and dumber playing it. The game had huge and bland lifeless environments similar to Far Cry 2 canyon-like map only with no vegetation. The Martian physics were also something that I just couldn't get used to; the game introduced the seemingly unnecessary destruction of everything even of civilian buildings; there was the un-tactical running and shooting gameplay even though there were some guerrilla type raids involved; ultimately most missions turned into run and shoot mess.

I had slight hopes for this game because I was hoping that the linear single player story would at least be something to enjoy.

Well, as for gameplay, this is a regular run'n'shoot BUT have-the-ability-to-destroy-everything game. There is no cover to speak of, and there's no ability to take cover and for a good reason - everything goes. That is, taking cover behind a wall will result in the wall being destroyed so you would attempt to kill the enemy before he or it kills you after blowing your cover, literally. There is no real tactical movement required - just keep on shooting and moving and you will most likely win.

As you descend deeper into the Martian caves you will encounter aliens. For the most part you are going to be battling angry insectoids, small roaches, giant roaches and some other disgusting creatures including huge mean looking worms. There's some suspense to have as you go deeper and deeper into caves and the CGI cut scenes are pretty cool however, this suspense is quickly dispensed by hordes of insects swarming you from every direction throughout the game. From that point on, the game pretty much becomes a giant insect fest comprised of killing as many bugs using different weapons as well as the environment before they get you. I think I've seen this somewhere, dare I say Lost Planet 2? Only that game had co-op.

Besides, for some reason, you will constantly encounter the ammo for your guns even in the deepest caves where no man has set foot. You will never run out of ammo because the ammo caches are spread out in almost every direction.

The portable computer system that you have, SAM, is reminiscent of the Dead Space navigation pointer, except this time, SAM has a voice and it tells you what to do constantly. You don't really have to think or wander around caves because the SAM guiding system will tell you where to go. The game practically plays by itself.

The weapons are okay. We have the usual guns as well as magnet gun that connects point A and B- this gives you the opportunity to hurl objects from point A at enemies that are located at point B. You can also destroy entire multiple story buildings and constructions with one placed shot.

The graphics are great, the DX 11 and all. The water looks okay and for the most part the environments are well detailed. The aliens are sometimes revolting to look at too.

You do have the ability to break through walls as well as re-construct virtually every man made structure via your molecular reconstructor or whatever, which is neat, but extremely unrealistic. So, in the end you end up with great looking engine that actually lets you destroy just about everything but at the same time lets you fix pretty much everything. Take that for what it's worth. There are also some weapon and skill upgrades you can buy with your easily earned credits.

I guess the biggest disappointment is the gameplay. You just want to keep running and shooting without looking back. Or you DO look back only to shoot up some chasing insectoids while keeping on running.

There are no invisible walls in the game but some battles requires you to stay within a set sector without having the ability to retreat. Thus you are given 10 seconds to get back into battle...

The game is also extremely easy, even on Hard. The health regenerates within a few seconds. The game itself runs smoothly though and the controls for your character are fluid. You will be able to move fast and avoid being hit.

All in all, buy the game at bargain.

reviewText:
Remember how amazing the destruction was in Red Faction Guerilla?  Where you could drive cars through walls, detonate the explosives as you bail out, and destroy an entire outpost while escaping in a missile tank?

Well you can't do that in this!  Enjoy fighting generic bug alien things while you have the most toned down destruction mechanics imaginable.  Sure they added some great guns like the magnet gun and the reconstructor, but it's so restricted and toned down that you go back to playing the old one.

tldr; go play red faction guerilla

reviewText:
I had never played a game of the Red Faction series until this one.  I have to say that despite the good things I heard about the series, either this one is defective or they all suck.  3/10

There is only one thing this game made badass: using vehicles.  Too bad the usage is few and far inbetween.  Everything else...and I mean EVERYTHING ELSE is borrowed from other games.  They don't add an exceptional twist to it either.  Game play is okay; not very intense and often monotonous.  The graphics and music are nothing special.  Storyline is probably stronger of these aspects, but its very predictable and is mainly improved because of a slightly better presentation.  Some of the level design is quite interesting, but with the rest of the game wholly against it, it is kind of like a feeble attempt at a come back.

What really kills this game is the dialogue.  For the entire duration of the game, you will hear the constant ♥♥♥♥♥ing and moaning of a guy about as masculine as Ryan Seacrest.  Whine whine whine whine whine whine whine whine whine whine.  It's like going on a road trip with a kid in the backseat that has massive cabin fever.  At first its like...well okay maybe he will shut up at some point.  Then it becomes...can I turn this off without missing anything?  FInally it evolves into concern for society at large, because you know they are trying to portray this guy as a wise-cracking masculine male, and anyone who believes he is so...well... Flying Spaghetti Monster HELP US.

Hello, i just finishesd this game and it has its pros and cons.

pros:
-the controls are easy to learn, because they're pretty basic

portals, the magnets attract eachother and collide. this allows you to be very creative, because you can make monsters fly
for very long distance so they smash into walls/ceilling etc. or you can smash monsters into eachother or even throw an whole building upon them.

reviewText: If you haven't played any of the Red faction games, you really should. There's nothing quite like them out there (although I haven't heard great things about RF2). There are so many ways to play - when you can destroy any structure in any way you want with any weapon, you suddenly have a lot of options.\nIn Armageddon, there is a new weapon called the magnet gun that lets you pull objects together (violently) and once you figure it out, it can be a lot of fun to use. Armageddon isn't open world like guerilla was and is more linear, which was disappointing but I still liked it. I also like the multiplayer, and play local games (LAN) with a friend of mine. You can upgrade your character with salvage" you earn - however the time you have to choose upgrades between rounds is short and often the round starts before I can choose (possibly because my friend started the round).\nAll and all
date: a very worthy addition to your collection."

reviewText:
This one was the first game of the series that I played, and definately it won't be the last. Most things I have to say about it are between good and great.

Storyline is very good, gives you a brief awareness of what happened before the game, without spoiling the previous games, so you still feel like you must play them in order to fully understand the whole picture. Graphics are good, the destruction engine is awesome and opens a huge door for creativity. I mean, why waste ammo when you can crush a building down with your maul and let gravity kill your enemies for you? The Magnet Gun is in my personal top 3 of best video game weapons of all time. It's incredibly fun to use, and gives you an unlimited advantage over your enemy, with its unlimited ways to bring tangos down, from crushing them with one another to drag them next to you so you can be able to finish em with meele.

On the other hand, I wouldn't say single player campaign is short, but it sure is a little easy, even in the insane difficulty. Sound is not extraordinary, I think it could be somewhat more intense, in order to match with the graphics and make you feel more inside of the action.

In the end, I think it is a must have/play. 8/10

Now let's get the rest of the series :P

reviewText:
English:
Red Faction: Armageddon is the best sequel we could ask: the series has reach a new evolution not only by improving its peculiar elements, but also by taking elements from other games and mixing them, and the result is not a mere clone of other products. If this isn't enough, the multiplayer mode will surely guarantee hours and hours of crazy co-op alien slautghing.
On the negative, many fans of the series will probably not like the change of scenery, which had totally left behind the political background of the previous episodes.
Anyway, if you enjoy killing aliens and making things explode, this is probably your game.


Italian:
Red Faction Armageddon è ciò che di meglio si poteva desiderare per la saga: il gioco si è evoluto non solo sulle sue basi ma anche implementando in ottimo modo elementi e particolarità di altri prodotti, pur distanziandosi da questi, e soprattutto non risultando il solito banale clone di “un gioco con tizi grossi che corrono, sparano e si nascondono” (già banale di suo, ndr). Se non bastasse, l’ottimo multiplayer garantisce ore di (in)sano massacro alieno cooperativo. Ciò che invece mette dubbi è il cambio di volta nella trama, che potrebbe allontanare coloro che amavano lo stile fanta-politico dei precedenti capitoli, e che sebbene apprezzabile è tutt’altro che originale e priva di stereotipi. Ad ogni modo, se vi piace fare esplodere le cose e ridurre a brandelli alieni, senza disdegnare meccaniche meno ignoranti della media, Armageddon è il titolo che fa per voi.

Leggete la recensione completa qui: http://www.gamesource.it/red-faction-armageddon-recensione-red-faction-armageddon/

reviewText:
This is a typical case of developers not understanding what is good about their product. There is a way to play this game that is hugely entertaining. But there are also ways to make it incredibly boring.

The right way to play this game is very simple: ignore everything that doesn't cause explosions.There's nothing satisfying about sniping jumpy aliens with a laser pistol. What is fun is blowing the alien and the building it was clinging on to shreds. Explosions are such a cliche that it is hard to explain how well it works here. We're not talking just about fancy animations and light effects. This game's destruction model makes a spectacle out of every single rocket, making holes into buildings and sending parts flying everywhere.

The game tries to be more than its physics model, and it fails miserably. The story is actually so bad that it had me laughing all the way through. But you owe it to yourself to pick up a rocket launcher and blow something up. It's so good that it doesn't even get old for the 6 hours that the game lasts.

reviewText:
Generally this is a good game. Good cutscenes. Cool characters. Fun Gameplay.

What my problem was are the cutscene loading. This seems to be a common issue. At least i found several people reporting the same problem. Everytime a cutscene loads (this includes the creation of a new game) the game just returns to the main menu.
In Direct X9 it was possible to restart the game and by pressing several times on continue or load game eventually the cutscene run through and did not just return to the main menu.

I managed to play through this game using this method ... but this was somethimes really annoying ...

So what to recommend? If you do not have this problem - totally recommend. If you have the probem - NO :D

And one remark. Play on Hard. I used normal and after a few upgrades it was just to easy. The final battle has no challenge at all. Beserk + Rocket Launcher = everything dead before it touches you.

reviewText: A fantastic game that has awesome gameplay and a great story to go with it. The single player is the perfect length to get it all done. There is a survival mode in online were you get waves of monsters. The graphics make you feel like your watching a movie. The guns are creative and well done. The over all game is an amazing adventure. Ive loved playing this and if your into shooters then dont hesitate when seeing this one in the price range that pleases you. Its diamond in the rough!

reviewText: After the excellent Red Faction Guerrilla, this is quite the disappointment. Linear and little stuff to blow up. Graphics look pretty good, and, in comparison to Guerrilla, this is a great port; solid 60fps all the way and lots of options. There are a lot of fantastic weapons (<3 Mr. Toots) so the action is pretty good, but it's just an endless spawn of alien enemies in the end. I lost interest pretty quickly. And most of the time you have to kill them to continue. I really missed the freedom of Guerrilla, and using my sledgehammer to kill the enemies. Because of the small caves, you usually use one of yours guns, especially when you're being surrounded by 10+ enemies. So yes, it's more action packed than Guerrilla (the powers you can acquire are a plus actually), but blowing things up and the whole freedom aspect were two of the things that made the previous game so great. Remember the Dragon Age 2 criticism ? It's just like that all over again. Get it when it's cheap.\n\n[Rating: 82/100]

reviewText:
Pros:

Destruction mechanics coupled with Magnet Gun and other new additions change up shooter gameplay
Great graphics and solid shooter gameplay
Decent, if somewhat unremarkable, story
Lots of opportunities for vehicle combat that can be pretty fun, without dragging on
Fun-to-chase achievements will get players using Darius’ various abilities and weapons
New Game Plus feature and purchasable cheats will draw players back to the campaign

Cons:

Somewhat repetitive cave environments
Alien enemies aren’t really all that much fun to fight
Destruction mechanics aren’t really balanced with shooter mechanics — you get blasted a lot
While carries some great fresh ideas, still very similar to other offerings in the genre

reviewText:
This game got a lot of heat from people for not being a sandbox game like it's predecessor.

However, I think that it is better in a way. Instead of wandering around doing missions, you're guided through a more linear, richer story. Half-Life 2 wasn't a sandbox game, and people loved that...

Graphically and audibly, this game is brilliant. The physics and destruction is the best I have ever seen in a game. Blowing everthing up and having the ability to repair stuff with the nanoforge is extremely fun. The gameplay actually takes advantage of both of these, so I think it meshes quite well, and it isn't just a gimmick.

Story wise; it's okay. Better than Guerilla (personally)

Should you buy it? YES. This is one of THQ's underrated games for sure. Don't listen to the haters.

reviewText:
I went into this thinking it would be like the last Red Faction game - Open world sandbox... But this wasn't open anything.

This is Gears of War meets Red Faction.  Linear levels, lots of one liners, cocky action hero, and your standard fare of Mine-Cart rides, Mech battles, and things exploding.

All and all - a well made, fun action game.  Its a third person shooter with a lot of fun weapons and most buildings break part in peices like the older Red Faction games.

I recommend for those that like Movie" style action games with low difficulty.  I had a lot of fun because I beat it in 8 hours going slow... trying to kill everything with just a hammer. :-)"

reviewText: Red Faction Armageddon may have been a failure according to critics, but I had a surprising amount of fun demolishing and restoring objects, blasting enemies, and upgrading my abilities to accomplish the aforementioned activities more effectively. The plot is cheesy and predictable, and gameplay can be repetitive at times, but it's easy to look past the flaws and enjoy the game as a whole for the most part. I also found the game to have more replay value than I expected, allowing you to carry your stats and upgrades over to a new playthrough.\nPick it up while it's on sale.

reviewText:
[9/10] - When I bought Armageddon, I was hoping for the same open world experience I got from Guerilla. Unfortunately, what I got was a linear story progression that didn't have the same charm as its predecessor. However, that does not at all mean it's a bad game. In fact, I enjoyed the game just as much as, if not more than, the other one.

The combat in Armageddon is fluid and well played. Swinging the hammer to destroy almost every piece of the world and then bringing it back to life by repairing it in an instant allows for total control over the battlefield. There are upgrades such as shockwave which pushes your enemies away, berserk which increases damage output, and creating a defensive shell that reflects bullets. These are all unlocked through progression and can be allocated to the enhancement of your choice,  giving a noticeable and substantial edge in combat. There is also a wide choice of weapons to choose from including dual pistols, machine guns, and a rocket launcher along with its own unique array of weapons like the magnet gun and rail driver. I never felt more powerful in a game bashing enemies as a single-hero-against-all-odds than I have in Armageddon.

There is also a four player co-op mode where you fight waves of enemies or complete objectives (usually defending structures) that can be enjoyable with friends. There are 15 maps total and 30 waves each, leaving plenty of variety and content to satisfy this game mode for a while.

On the downside, the game is a bit short and doesn't offer too much in terms of difficulty, at least for me. Though time has passed, and price has dropped and I would HIGHLY recommend giving this game a chance. It's a fun and exciting third person shooter that has not received the love it deserves.

reviewText: If you haven't played any of the Red faction games, you really should. There's nothing quite like them out there (although I haven't heard great things about RF2). There are so many ways to play - when you can destroy any structure in any way you want with any weapon, you suddenly have a lot of options.\nIn Armageddon, there is a new weapon called the magnet gun that lets you pull objects together (violently) and once you figure it out, it can be a lot of fun to use. Armageddon isn't open world like guerilla was and is more linear, which was disappointing but I still liked it. I also like the multiplayer, and play local games (LAN) with a friend of mine. You can upgrade your character with salvage" you earn - however the time you have to choose upgrades between rounds is short and often the round starts before I can choose (possibly because my friend started the round).\nAll and all
date: a very worthy addition to your collection."

reviewText:
I really enjoyed this game, and it's one of those games that just stuck with me after I've finished it. The story is not bad at all, and keeps you invested from the beginning to the end. The game is very linear and there's not many options other than whats presented to you. However I don't find that a bad thing, I actually think the game benefits from it. This is not a game that you walk around exploring your enviroment or wander off on some side quest, but rather sit back and enjoy as the story unfolds itself. It's decently long and can accomplish this without making the game feel repetitiv.

Now let's talk about the best part, the destruction. A lot of stuff in your environment will break, and I mean a lot. You can bash through a wall with your sledgehammer and tear down pillars and buildings to their core. This means that you can destroy any cover that the enemy might try and hide behind, but so can they. You can repair stuff to quickly make cover for yourself or you can grab a piece of a wall and swing it on your enemies. It never gets boring and will make a huge difference in how you play the game.

Aside from the single-player action you can team up with some friends and play coop missions. These center around fighting waves of enemies while trying to survive. I found this to be very fun and intense gameplay, but it falls short when it comes to veriety and exensivness.

If you can find this game on a sale, I would highly recommend it.

reviewText:
While not open world like it's predecessor RFG, RFA brings more great tech to the pitch.  In fact the tech is more prominent due the closed nature of the level design.  Explicitly stated RFA is without doubt one of the most technically impressive works that I have ever interacted with. Volition proves themselves again that they are leaders in their field.

An additional effect aside from the destruction the series has become known for is reconstruction enabling you, for example, to completely destroy a bridge during combat that's needed for level progression and later allowing you to rebuild it.

On the downside, from a PC perspective the FOV is too close and I've never really adjusted.  To compensate I've moved to a couch/plasma/cont setup so that I'm farther back from the screen.  While this improves the expereince it's not optimal.  On the upside the DX11 visuals are great given the console nature of the game.  The story is good enough though it takes time to develop.

reviewText:
Generally this is a good game. Good cutscenes. Cool characters. Fun Gameplay.

What my problem was are the cutscene loading. This seems to be a common issue. At least i found several people reporting the same problem. Everytime a cutscene loads (this includes the creation of a new game) the game just returns to the main menu.
In Direct X9 it was possible to restart the game and by pressing several times on continue or load game eventually the cutscene run through and did not just return to the main menu.

I managed to play through this game using this method ... but this was somethimes really annoying ...

So what to recommend? If you do not have this problem - totally recommend. If you have the probem - NO :D

And one remark. Play on Hard. I used normal and after a few upgrades it was just to easy. The final battle has no challenge at all. Beserk + Rocket Launcher = everything dead before it touches you.

reviewText:
This is a typical case of developers not understanding what is good about their product. There is a way to play this game that is hugely entertaining. But there are also ways to make it incredibly boring.

The right way to play this game is very simple: ignore everything that doesn't cause explosions.There's nothing satisfying about sniping jumpy aliens with a laser pistol. What is fun is blowing the alien and the building it was clinging on to shreds. Explosions are such a cliche that it is hard to explain how well it works here. We're not talking just about fancy animations and light effects. This game's destruction model makes a spectacle out of every single rocket, making holes into buildings and sending parts flying everywhere.

The game tries to be more than its physics model, and it fails miserably. The story is actually so bad that it had me laughing all the way through. But you owe it to yourself to pick up a rocket launcher and blow something up. It's so good that it doesn't even get old for the 6 hours that the game lasts.

reviewText:
Pros:

+Awesome destructive sandbox properties


Cons:

-Drab and boring story mode; linear and ♥♥♥♥♥♥
-Not enough content; when you beat it, you're done
-No expansive use of it's own boons; blow ♥♥♥♥ up! - but don't do anything with it


Overall: 5.0/10
All this game does is give you the simple - and fun - mechanic of blowing everything up, and watching it crumble, and if you want, you can repair it, and do it all over again.
Now, they take that, and do absolutely nothing worthy with it, they throw you into a boring linear storyline with nothing but gunfights with the atlernate objective of blowing a small thing up every now and again to give you the illusion that you can really tear stuff up, and get rewarded.

Aside from the storymode, you're given two other game modes to mess around in; the first being Horde mode (Or whatever it is) is where you pit yourself up solo, or even with some friends, to fend out waves and waves of the main enemy of the game. But that's all you really do in it, there's not much else to it, and you're not given anything for accomplishing it. The second is Ruin mode, where your goal is to destroy as much as you can as fast and chaoticly as you can, and even if that sounds like what this game was trying to give you in the first place, it doesn't feel that nice.

The weapon and fighting mechanics are just meh as the rest of it, get a few weapon slots for pre-defined weapons, and bang bang, hide to recover health, repeat. There's a few interesting weapon aresenals out there, but nothing that'll keep you hooked. The main enemy of the game is an alien race, but instead of clawing you to death with scythes or anything (which they have), they just shoot spikes at you all day. Again, another illusion of doing something unique, but it just masks the fact that they're all faceless soldier grunts.


Even with all this, I never played Guerilla, which I heard was way way WAY better and cooler. Yeah, it probably was.

reviewText:
TL;DR: Overall, it's a farily decent game. You have the Red Faction feel with complete and utter environmental carnage, but the storyline seems out of place.
Quick and Easy game, even on the highest difficulty.
Would overall not recommend.
_______

Dry Humor on a Dry Planet
I will forever love the little bits of comedy that came around during cinematics/gameplay.

Mason: SAM, show me where the bugs are.
-SAM gives locations. Mason sees the hive colony-
Mason: Buckle up, SAM. This may take a while.
SAM: There is no buckle up" directive in my drive.
Mason: -sigh- Just shut up and show me where the bugs are.
SAM: Affirmative.
It's those little chuckles that get you through it all.

However...
